awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Nanoparticle-based smell test device for COVID-19 screening
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of reliable rapid screening for COVID-19. The global COVID-19 diagnostics market is expanding rapidly. The market size is valued at $19.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.1% from 2021 to 2027. Compared to the existing smell tests, the proposed technology facilitates remote-controlled switching capacity of multiple odor molecules and instant auto-evaluation. The proposed device allows standardized emission of multiple odor molecules using a single device. Moreover, results from the device may be delivered directly through the app or over the web enabling testing in telemedicine settings. Since there is no reliable testing for rapid diagnosis of asymptomatic and presymptomatic COVID-19 cases, this technology may potentially change the paradigm of diagnosis.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a nanoparticle-based smell test device. The proposed nanoparticle-based system triggers the controlled release of specific molecules on demand. This smell test device has potential application in the diagnosis of diseases affecting the sense of smell. Since an impaired sense of smell is a distinct sign of COVID-19 in both asymptomatic and presymptomatic cases, this technology has the potential for screening and early diagnosis of the disease. Moreover, unlike traditional smell tests, the proposed technology is designed such that it may be configured into any form factor from a plate to a pen to incorporation in an inhalation device. This technique allows quantitative control of multiple scent intensities facilitating a new layer of detailed data that has hereto not been available. Understanding the impact of COVID-19 in olfaction will open new doors in diagnosis and disease management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our I-Corps team explored the marketing potential of a nanoparticle-based controlled release system for COVID-19 diagnosis and screening. Nanoparticle-based controlled release system is a unique approach which triggers the release of specific molecules on demand. Our quantitative smell device comprising of a nanoparticle-based controlled release system has potential applications in the diagnosis of diseases affecting the sense of smell such as COVID-19 and brain disorders and the smell training which helps patients regain the sense of smell.  

During the I-Corps program, the team consisting of two Entrepreneurial Leads, Technical Lead, and I-Corps Mentor conducted over 140 interviews with various people including COVID-19 patients, olfactory research experts, medical doctors, charity groups that help people with loss of smell, pharmacy managers, and marketing professionals. The initial interviews identified that smell-based testing and screening have a limited marketing potential due to logistic issues with implementation. In contrast, smell training for the COVID-19 long haulers suffering from the loss of smell showed better product market fit. The smell training device offers faster recovery time, reduced patients’ anxiety and household accidents, and improved quality of life as its value proposition. Further interviews identified key components in the business model canvas, such as the online retailers and social media platforms as the channels, olfactory research experts and medical doctors as the key partners, establishing a partnership with local companies, charity groups, and insurance companies as the key activities, and the device price range that would be acceptable to the potential customers.    

The key outcomes of this project include the product market fit of the smell training device, a complete business model canvas illustrating the important aspects in commercializing the smell training device, and the smell training device prototype as the minimum viable product.   

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2024
Modified by: Asahi Tomitaka
